title: Basics of International Law
headline: In this free online course, learn about the social functions, legal systems and principles of international law.
description: In this course, we will examine international law, its history and the differences between domestic and international law. We will then investigate the sources of international law, the role of international organisations, international trade law, international commercial law and the principles of the trading system. Next, we discuss some environmental problems and what role international environmental law plays in this context.
courseDescription:
The term ‘international law’ refers to public international legislation and this course will explore international law, its history and regulations and discuss how it differs from the private law of nations. We will also delve into the relationship between law and social psychology. Are you wondering what the sources of international law are and how it has evolved? We will cover this question before looking at the international law commission and regional as well as local customs. There is a connection between municipal and international law, commonly referred to as ‘public international law’. We will examine this association and the role of the United Nations and other international organisations around the globe. We will also explore the historical background of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and the European Union.

The course will discuss international human rights, including the fundamental principles and major conventions. We will examine various segments of private international law as well as sources and venues. Next, we will discuss international family law, marriage law, inheritance of assets and so on. Have you heard of international criminal law and want to know how crimes are treated under international law? We research sources of international criminal law and the role of the International Criminal Court and international humanitarian law in detail. We will then take an in-depth look at treaties' application, amendment and interpretation and cover critical areas such as legislative, executive and judicial jurisdiction.

Next, we will learn about various aspects of maritime law, such as the baseline, the bay, the territorial sea and the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. Are you wondering what international trade law and international arbitration are? We will discuss these topics and learn about international environmental law, ozone layer depletion and climate change issues. We will debate the precautionary principle, air pollution and nuclear activities. This course is ideal for law students or professionals who want to deepen their knowledge of international law. So why wait? Register today!

Start Course Now

slides:
• Introduction to International Law - Learning Outcomes

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain basic concepts of international law, its history, and how it differs from domestic law.
    • Summarize the international law commission, as well as regional and local customs.
    • Discuss international law before municipal courts as well as customary international law in detail.
    • Describe the connection between municipal law and international law.
    • Outline the role of the United Nations, the Security Council, and the General Assembly.
    • Discuss the development of international human rights law and ideal approaches to human rights.
    • Summarize the segments of private international law, along with the sources and domicile.

  • Introduction to International Law - Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module, Introduction to International Law are:
    • International law is a series of treaties and agreements between nations that regulate how nations deal with other nations, residents of other nations, and corporations of other nations. 
    • State practice is how states behave in practice that forms the basis of customary law, but evidence of what a state does can be obtained from numerous sources.
    • The general rule about municipal law's role in the international arena is that a state that violates an international law stipulation cannot defend itself by pointing to its domestic legal situation. 
    • North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), a military alliance founded on April 4, 1949, to provide a counterweight to Soviet armies stationed in central and eastern Europe following World WAR II.
    • The concept of human rights is closely allied with ethics and morality, which reflect a community's values and will be those with the most chance of successful implementation.
    • In addition to the numerous international and regional treaty provisions concerning human rights, some human rights can also be considered customary international law based on state practice. 
    • Private International Law or International Private Law determines the choice of law to apply. The main origins of Private International Law are national legislation.

  • International Laws of Treaties and Territories - Learning Outcomes

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss international criminal law, crimes under international law, and the sources of international criminal law.
    • Explain the application, modification, and interpretation of treaties.
    • Outline the principles of Domestic Jurisdiction and the Universality Principle.
    • Summarize the jurisdictional nature of the territorial sea and international straits.
    • Outline principles of International Trade Law and International Trading System.
    • Discuss the principles of International Environmental Law and the basic duties of the state.
    • Describe the rules of International Commercial Law and International Arbitration.

  • International Criminal Law

  • International Laws of Treaties and Territories - Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module, International Laws of Treaties and Territories are:
    • Criminal Law is paradigmatically concerned with laws aimed against persons, violations of which are punished by a State.
    • The ICC Statute contains its own set of sources to apply, which are analogous, although by no means identical, to those in the ICI state.
    • Treaties may be drafted between states, governments, heads of states, or governmental departments, whichever appears the most expedient.
    • Territorial sovereignty can be defined in the terms of the existence of rights over territory rather than the state's independence or the relation of persons to persons.
    • All the waters within baseline are archipelagic waters over which the state has sovereignty, but traditional fishing rights and existing submarine cables must be respected.
    • International trade attorneys may concentrate on applying domestic laws to international trade and the application of treaty-based international laws regulating trade.
    • A wide range of environmental issues is atmospheric pollution, marine pollution, global warming, ozone depletion, and the effects of nuclear and other extra-hazardous substances.
